metadata.case_name: Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Company Limited

facts.text: Mahomedali Habib and Sakerkhanoo Mahomedali Habib carried on business as merchants and pucca adatias in bullion and companyton at Bombay under the name Habib Sons.

In 1948, Habib Sons instituted Summary Suit No. 233 of 1948 in Bombay City Civil Court against Jugalkishore Saraf for recovery of Rs. 7,113-7-0 with interest at 6% per annum in respect of transactions in gold and silver.

On 7th February 1949, while suit pending, document executed whereby Habib Sons transferred to Raw Cotton Company Limited all book and other debts due in connection with their business in Bombay, full benefit of securities, and all other property to which entitled in connection with said business.
Raw Cotton Company did not apply under O. XXII r. 10 CPC to substitute as plaintiffs; suit continued in name of original plaintiffs Habib Sons.
Two partners of Habib Sons migrated from India to Pakistan; their properties vested in Custodian of Evacuee Property.

On 15th December 1949, decree passed in summary suit in favour of Habib Sons for Rs. 8,018-7-0 principal and interest, Rs. 410 costs, total Rs. 8,428-7-0, with further interest at 4% from decree date.
On 2nd August 1950, Additional Custodian confirmed transfer of business of Habib Sons to Raw Cotton Company.
On 11th December 1950, Custodian informed Raw Cotton Company of confirmation.

On or about 25th April 1951, Raw Cotton Company presented tabular statement as execution application under O. XXI r. 11 CPC, praying for declaration as assignees of decree due to transfer by deed dated 7th Feb 1949 confirmed by Custodian, and substitution.
No specification of mode of assistance under clause (j) O. XXI r. 11 in application.
On 10th May 1951, City Civil Court issued notice under O. XXI r. 16 to Habib Sons and Jugalkishore Saraf to show cause why decree should not be executed by transferees.
Jugalkishore Saraf filed affidavit on 15th June 1951 denying execution of document and that it transferred decree.
Execution of document proved by attesting witness, accepted by executing court.
Executing court rejected contention on transfer, made notice absolute with costs, gave leave to execute.
Jugalkishore appealed to High Court (Appeal No. 67 of 1952), heard by Dixit J., execution of document not challenged, dismissed affirming lower court relying on Bombay HC cases.
Letters Patent Appeal No. 8 of 1953 to Bombay HC, dismissed by Chagla CJ and Shah J., certificate under Art 133(1)(c) granted.

legal_issues.text: Whether the respondent company can claim to be the transferees of the decree within the meaning of Order XXI, rule 16 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
Whether the document dated 7th February 1949 constituted an assignment of the future decree or operated in equity to transfer the decree upon its passing.
Whether respondents became transferees by operation of law under Order XXI r.16.
Whether respondents can execute under section 146 CPC as persons claiming under the decree-holder.

petitioner_arguments.text: Document dated 7th February 1949 executed before decree passed on 15th December 1949, so no transfer of decree by assignment in writing as required by O.XXI r.16.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Order XXI r.16 CPC; literal construction

petitioner_arguments.text: Document transfers book debts and existing property, not future decree; no mention of suit or decree.
Equitable principle does not create assignment in writing or by operation of law for O.XXI r.16.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Holroyd v. Marshall; Order XXI r.16 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Execution application defective under O.XXI r.11 as no mode of assistance specified.

respondent_arguments.text: Document transfers all book debts and other property in connection with business, including benefit of pending suit and future decree.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Transfer of Property Act s.8; equitable assignment

respondent_arguments.text: Equitable principle fastens on future decree upon passing, constituting assignment in writing or by operation of law under O.XXI r.16.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Holroyd v. Marshall; Collyer v. Isaacs; Purmananddas Jivandas v. Vallabdas Wallji; Chimanlal Hargovinddas v. Ghulamnabi

court_reasoning.text: Literal construction of O.XXI r.16 requires decree to exist before transfer by assignment in writing; document pre-dates decree, no transfer thereunder.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No apparent absurdity in literal reading.

court_reasoning.text: Document transfers existing book debts and property entitled to at date, not future decree; no specific mention of suit/decree; s.8 TPA passes only then-existing interests.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No agreement to transfer future decree.

court_reasoning.text: Equitable principle (treating as done what ought to be done) does not relate back to make prior agreement an assignment in writing; transfer by equity is by operation of equity, not document.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Equity fastens on after-acquired property but prior document not assignment under r.16.

court_reasoning.text: Transfer by operation of law includes equitable principle effects, court sales, insolvency, etc., not limited to death/succession; but no agreement, so no equity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Operation of law: passing by force of law, statutory or otherwise.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents as assignees of debt (subject-matter of suit) are real owners of decree passed thereon; claim under decree-holders as benamidars continued suit; entitled under s.146 CPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.146 applies where not transferees under r.16 but claim under decree-holder.

court_reasoning.text: Execution application defect under O.XXI r.11 waived as not objected to and subsequent compliant application filed.

holdings.text: Document does not transfer or agree to transfer future decree; no assignment in writing or by operation of law under O.XXI r.16.
Equitable assignment does not constitute transferee under O.XXI r.16 by prior document.
Respondents entitled to execute decree under s.146 CPC as persons claiming under decree-holders, being assignees of debt.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held assignee entitled by equitable assignment or operation of law; SC views as operation of law possible but not applicable here.
Transfer of rights under award/decree; intention clear.
Equitable principle for future property: equity compels performance, transfers beneficial interest.
Contract to assign future property becomes complete assignment in equity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Performing Right Society v. London Theatre of Varieties
precedents_cited.relevance: Equity does not make prior agreement statutory assignment; equitable owners not legal assignees.
Transfer of property in suit without decree transfer does not entitle to execute as decree transferee.
No equity to construe r.16 for pre-decree assignment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mathurapore Zamindary Co. Ltd. v. Bhasaram Mandal
precedents_cited.relevance: No execution under r.16 for pre-decree transfer.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs execution by transferees of decree; s.146 for persons claiming under; application requirements.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer passes existing interests, legal incidents, securities for debts/actionable claims.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed with costs; respondents entitled to execute decree under s.146 CPC as assignees of debt claiming under decree-holders, though not transferees under O.XXI r.16.

key_quotes.text: The principal question urged before us is as to whether the respondent company can claim to be the transferees of the decree within the meaning of Order XXI, rule 16 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The cardinal rule of construction of statutes is to read the statute literally, that is by giving to the words used by the legislature their ordinary, natural and grammatical meaning.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for interpreting O.XXI r.16 strictly.

key_quotes.text: Equity fastens upon the after-acquired property and treats the beneficial interest therein as transferred to the intending transferee.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The respondent company are entitled under section 146 to make the application for execution which the original decree-holders could do.
key_quotes.speaker: court
